text: Thumbs up for <@U01BLESEU1E>’s approach. I find it extremely helpful to almost start a conversation with myself about what's going on when I have that "nihilistic kind of burnout". I'd literally start with that question: "Is any of this even worth it?" - and then see what answers come up. From there, I dig deeper. And I've made the experience that the answers are neither difficult nor do they call for a huge load of action. It's usually small adjustments that help dealing with the situation that bothers me.

text: At the risk of being flippant, I'd historically deal with that via resignation letter.

elements.text: At the risk of being flippant, I'd historically deal with that via resignation letter.

text: I say this because if I caught myself using the words "nihilistic" and "burnout" to describe my feelings about work, this would have been a huge red flag that I'd let things go way too far.

elements.text: I say this because if I caught myself using the words "nihilistic" and "burnout" to describe my feelings about work, this would have been a huge red flag that I'd let things go way too far.

text: Anytime I found that work was turning me into someone I wasn't and someone that I didn't like, I'd pause and reflect on the aphorism about improving things at work, "work to change your company... or work to change companies."

elements.text: Anytime I found that work was turning me into someone I wasn't and someone that I didn't like, I'd pause and reflect on the aphorism about improving things at work, "work to change your company... or work to change companies."

text:
I appreciate all of you for responding wish such great ideas! And you all make good points — definitely need to start making some creative time that’s separate from work. Thank you for your genuine insights!

<@U017XD7H4P7> this actually made me laugh. For a lot of people I would totally agree, but I probably throw the word nihilistic around a little more carelessly than some people. In this case it’s very much “It’s not you, it’s me.” I get frustrated and antsy, but I know that I have to work through that at least most of the time. And that’s where I am now. You’re really, really, really f’ing right about “work to change your company” though. I love my company, but I do tend to sit back and let other people take the lead on things. This is a good reminder to take agency - at work and in life. Appreciate you!
